channel.title: My first (very basic) program
channel.description:

That is my black and white image converting software.
can i have a rating on it please?
thanks
*~bill~*

item.title: My first (very basic) program
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:11, topic:305770”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=402002.msg2979743#msg2979743 date=1254535770]
abraham, you should probably do some error checking on the input. Checking if the input file exists is a must, checking if it is a valid image file would be good as well. Also checking if the output file is a valid location should be done, and you don’t check if you need to create any folders for the output file either.
[/quote]no need, the app will throw an exception for this (ie a FileNotFoundException if the input file doesnt exist) and print it to the console[/quote]

Generally, a noob will see the stack trace and go ‘HELP HELP’ (if this were an actual commercial app), but you could’ve just argued that this wasn’t intended for noobs.

Read full topic

item.title: My first (very basic) program
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

  1. Use proper conventions for the sake of my currently bleeding eyes.
  2. You declare width and height as a double, then cast to an integer, why?
  3. What’s the need for width or height to be variables?
  4. Why declare “bimg” as null then assign it a value two lines later? Just declare it when you initiate it.
  5. Use printStackTrace() for your errors.
  6. You should allow user input for the saving and loading names and locations. HINT: http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/uiswing/components/filechooser.html

That’s at first glance. However, stick with the language and your habits will improve.

@abraham
nvm, im a moron

Read full topic

item.title: My first (very basic) program
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

that code can be reduced to

[code]
import java.awt.image.BufferedImage;
import java.io.File;
import javax.imageio.ImageIO;

class BlackAndWhite {

public static void main(String[] args) {
    if (args.length != 2) {
        System.out.println("Usage: java BlackAndWhite <in_pic_file> <out_pic_file>");
        return;
    }
    try {    
        BufferedImage img = ImageIO.read(new File(args[0));
        BufferedImage bwimg = new BufferedImage(img.getWidth(), img.getHeight(), BufferedImage.TYPE_BYTE_GRAY);
        bwimg.getGraphics().drawImage(img, 0, 0, null);
        ImageIO.write(bwimg, "jpg", new File(args[1]));
    } catch(Exception e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }
}

}[/code]and this one is better since it doesnt have the need to be re-compiled to perform the conversion on another file, you simply pass command line args

Read full topic

item.title: My first (very basic) program
item.dc:creator: @933pm 933pm
item.description:
@933pm wrote:

[code]//coverting colored image to black and white ~ made by bill
//Coding in java ~ sarry about conventions
//© Bill 2009 (Under Bills Licence)
//using a single class for ease.
//enjoy using
//current input: name
//current output: blackandwhite
//simple imports.
import java.awt.image.;
import javax.imageio.ImageIO;
import java.io.;
import java.awt.*;

//start of class
class BlackAndWhite
{
public static void main(String asr[])
{
try
{
//colored image path ~ change to your file destination
BufferedImage image = ImageIO.read(new File(".\Folder\Input\NAME.jpg"));

//getting width and height of image
double image_width = image.getWidth();
double image_height = image.getHeight();
//reading the image
BufferedImage bimg = null;
BufferedImage img = image;
//end of
//drawing a new image
bimg = new BufferedImage((int)image_width, (int)image_height, BufferedImage.TYPE_BYTE_GRAY);
//creating some graphics
Graphics2D gg = bimg.createGraphics();
//redrawing teh image using image.getHeight(); && image.getWidth();
gg.drawImage(img, 0, 0, img.getWidth(null), img.getHeight(null), null);

//saving black and white image onto drive
String temp = “blackandwhite.jpeg”;
File fi = new File(".//Folder//Output//" + temp);
//format .jpeg
ImageIO.write(bimg, “jpg”, fi);
}
//throwing a catch exception
catch (Exception e)
{
//prints out
System.out.println(e);
}
}
}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: My first (very basic) program
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

In future, attach the program to your post, and posting some of the source code is also a plus.

In all honesty, I am far too lazy and can’t be fucked to actually download your code then scrutinize it, however if you had posted some or all of it in your first post, within code tags, then I and others would be much more likely to give it a once-over.
